$ make peer

<@U0Z41KY5V> strange, looking now

yeah, that is orthogonal
"make gotools" was meant as a way to install the tools locally, the ccenv is doing its own installation of protoc-gen-go
for whatever reason, the latter is broken for you
im just firing up my rig now, will see if I can reproduce
yes, thanks for your help~~
I was not able to reproduce the issue
can you provide any more detail of your setup?

strange
no, you shouldnt need to

this is on OSX

it was built on line 12, and installed on line 33
ubuntu should be fine too

line 12 of fabric/Makefile?
no, of my snippet
aha, so u mean if run `make peer`, then protoc-gen-go will be installed automatically, correct?
correct, or at least, that is the intention
<@U0KPFAZNF>  are you running it in a virtualbox or native on mac os?
and at least in my case, that holds true
thanks, i will clean the env and retry, just to make sure.
<@U36UDC6RK> native on osx
okay thx
I fixed the build recently in master so it doesnt rely on the virtubox setup for much of anything
great!
(though the doc still lags behind and implies it is more critical than it really is)
we need a quick dev env on baremetal sometimes.
yes, that is what this is essentially
basically all you need is a handful of things: make, git, golang v1.6+, docker
and you can build fabric baremetal
at least on linux and OSX
i am not sure if windows is that easy
do note, however, that running the full suite (like unit-tests) may only work with docker-for-mac, not the older docker-machine
(the build will work with either, but the unit tests need the newer docker setup)
aha, i guess that might be because there was some old images in my system. then it may ignore install protoc-gen-go?
<@U0Z41KY5V> possibly, can you show me your build/docker fs?
sure, will post, am doing a clean re-make
what I dont understand is: make is governed purely by the files that are present
and can i know what part in the makefile build/install the protoc-gen-go?
so either the file is present, and it will skip it, or its not, and it will build it

```
$ ls build/docker                                                                                            2 ↵
gotools
```
but your error implies it was not there
sorry, i meant full tree if you have it
tree build/docker
lots of things actually
but ls build/docker/gotools/bin, there is nothing
can i know what part in the makefile build/install the protoc-gen-go? not find it inside
sure, hold on
so, this is the rule that would be responsible for building it
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/Makefile#L148>
this is what causes ccenv to depend on it: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/Makefile#L177>
can you do run "make clean && make peer" and send me the output you are seeing?
aha, so it was triggered by `build/image/ccenv/payload`
yes: image -> payload -> stuff
in this case ccenv -> ccenv/payload -> protoc-gen-go
<@U0YQK8WSV|pvishnum> has joined the channel
interesting, i noticed when i clean all stuffs with the images, then it can work! but when there’s some remaining images/broken during the make process, then the 2nd round will fail
ok, thats probably a makefile bug of some kind
i may suggest we decouple the image building from comping a native binary like peer/orderer.
if you can file as much detail as possible in a JIRA, appreciated
don’t think there’s reason to combine them building together :disappointed:
well, the coupling was created intentionally
ccenv must exist for peer to run, but I suppose we could provide the option
to your point, its not actually needed to build peer, but it is needed to run peer so I wanted to ensure "peer xxx" was ready to run when the command finished
yes, and if so we may let developers know that explicitly in the docs, instead of hiding into scripts. sometimes, we just wanna build out a binary locally or just build a image.
i suspect removing the coupling will make things more error prone for users
s/users/devs
i guess this follows linux style? make each piece focus, while combine as users like to?
i guess...but a counter point is: whatever you are stumbling on is a bug
we can paper over it by getting rid of the ccenv step, but really we should just fix the underlying issue
normally, ccenv would build, it would be cached, and then youd never have to deal with it again
yes, and now it seems a little hard to dig it out as lots of things are comping together. However i will create an issue at the jira and let u know. thanks greg!
ok
ill give the decoupling more thought, but I think that would cause more problems
i understand your point though
yes, let me dig more on the makefile first. see can find what hint for the error :slightly_smiling_face:
ok
<@U0Z41KY5V> pls do send me the output of your build sequence that reproduces this, ideally including the initial build that worked and the subsequent builds that fail
sure, greg~~
<@U0KPFAZNF> just create it here: <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1412>
ty

initial_comment.comment: <@U2Q0HP4HY> something is not kosher with your ccenv image

text: did you do anything custom to generate it, or was this simply what came out of a normal build?
<@U36UDC6RK> ah, yes, the answer is simple
OSX ships with bsdtar, but the build expects switches that are gnutar specific
Well I went back to running in vagrant. I run the same sdk test and it worked
what most of us have done is used homebrew to replace bsdtar with gnutar...i can guide if that is acceptable to you
yes sure, that would be nice
<@U36UDC6RK> ok, let me look it up, standby
<@U36UDC6RK> i think you want "brew install gnu-tar --with-default-names"
the last option makes it install it as /usr/local/bin/tar rather than /usr/local/bin/gtar
so, as long as /usr/local/bin eclipses your default OSX bsdtar, that should do it
<@U2Q0HP4HY> ok, I am not sure what went wrong, but your ccenv image seems to be corrupt somehow
but glad you can work around it in the vagrant setup for now
ok thx a bunch ...
<@U0KPFAZNF> thanks alot, the make process was successful now!
we need to get that in a wiki/faq somewhere
<@U0KM61BCP> any thoughts as to best placement of the bsdtar/gnutar thing for OSX?
you mean in the docs?
<@U0KPFAZNF> I have a changeset open that I can add this to
<@U0Z81GL6S|anya> has left the channel

<@U3FUEPPF1>  I don't have any answers, but, just to let you know, you're not the only one hitting this...  just ran into this this morning myself....I hadn't worked with vagrant and master for a few weeks (I usually work on z Systems).   Hopefully somebody here can help.
